<div class="image-alt" itemprop="description">Bank of China had opened its maiden Indian branch in Mumbai in June last year. (AFP file photo)</div>

<div class="story-movie"><div class="movie-detail"></div></div>
<div class="description " itemprop="articleBody">
<p>Anti-China sentiment in India is high since the bloody clashes in Ladakh’s Galwan Valley led to the martyrdom of 20 Indian soldiers. Amid this, a post on social media claims Bank of China is opening its first Indian branch in Mumbai despite calls to boycott Chinese products and services.</p>
<p>The viral post on <b><a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/481283325377304/permalink/1596610437177915/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Facebook</a> </b>carries with it a screenshot of an ANI tweet that says, “Reserve Bank of India issues licences to Bank of China to operate in India. This was a commitment made by PM Modi to Chinese leadership: Sources”.<b> </b></p>
<div class="itgimage"> <img class="lazyload" data-src="https://akm-img-a-in.tosshub.com/indiatoday/images/bodyeditor/202006/pic_1_6-x544.png?n.mxMZ2Y8ejnoU1jeHt0E7X89dLJdC3L" src="https://akm-img-a-in.tosshub.com/indiatoday/../sites/all/themes/itg/images/itg_image370x208.jpg" alt=""><div class="body_caption"></div>
</div>
<p>India Today Anti Fake News War Room (AFWA) has found the claim to be misleading. It is an old development that has resurfaced in the backdrop of recent border clashes between Indian and Chinese troops.</p>
<p>Bank of China had opened its maiden Indian branch in Mumbai in June last year. The ANI tweet, whose date has been cropped out in the viral post, is two years old. The Reserve Bank of India had issued the license to the Bank of China in 2018.</p>
<p>The archived version of the post can be seen <b><a href="http://archive.today/iFqMy" target="_blank" rel="noopener">here</a></b>. Multiple Facebook users have shared the post believing it to be a recent one.</p>
<div class="itgimage"> <img class="lazyload" data-src="https://akm-img-a-in.tosshub.com/indiatoday/images/bodyeditor/202006/pic_2_3-x578.png?PMSnwjPCINHrbMapigTJO2uo8QYDjZcC" src="https://akm-img-a-in.tosshub.com/indiatoday/../sites/all/themes/itg/images/itg_image370x208.jpg" alt=""><div class="body_caption"></div>
</div>
<p>With the help of keyword search, we found <b><a href="https://www.thehindu.com/business/bank-of-china-starts-india-operations/article27473233.ece#:~:text=Bank%20of%20China%2C%20one%20of,a%20maiden%20branch%20in%20Mumbai." target="_blank" rel="noopener">news articles</a> </b>related to the Bank of China opening its <b><a href="https://sputniknews.com/business/201903201073391217-chinese-bank-opens-branch-india/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">first branch</a> </b>in India. According to these news reports, the branch had opened in Mumbai in June 2019.</p>
<p>With the help of advanced tweet search, we found that the ANI tweet superimposed on the claim was actually posted two years ago.</p>
<div class="inline-story-add" style="width:100%;height:99px;"><div class="itg_js_ad_load_loop" id="div-gpt-ad-1559542262710-0"></div></div>
<p>On July 4, 2018, news agency ANI <b><a href="https://twitter.com/ANI/status/1014385067853058048" target="_blank" rel="noopener">tweeted</a> </b>that RBI has issued a license to Bank of China to operate in India. “<a href="https://www.hindustantimes.com/business-news/bank-of-china-gets-rbi-licence-to-open-branch-in-india/story-AGAJHz0LrDQSNkF0aerHLO.html?fbclid=IwAR35q4DsMTaP50nXCR5iKXiGFaShItPk-2U2-QGjV3zHsjZPxgpigZxUpcY" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Hindustan Times</b></a>” had also reported the same on July 4, 2018.</p>
<p>The report said, “Prime Minister Narendra Modi had made a commitment to Chinese President Xi Jinping to allow Bank of China to set up branches in India when they met on the sidelines of the SCO summit in the Chinese city of Qingdao last month.”</p>
<p>Therefore, the viral claim of Bank of China opening its first Indian branch in Mumbai amid border tensions between the two countries is misleading. The branch had opened last year and the license was issued two years back.</p>
